And having seen it for so many years and from every angle as governor, as a lawyer, attorney general to the governor in the state agencies, as mayor, I've looked at it in a number of ways and I think I can pull it together.

But why do think that you can do it?

I believe the mounting frustration, the seriousness of the fiscal crisis will instill in the legislators a deeper desire and commitment to getting the job done.
You can sail along for a while but when the ship is going under, the crew pulls together.
Weve had recessions before.
Weve had very high unemployment before, and it comes back.
The key is not to squander the revenue that the taxpayers give us and to pull together as both Republicans and Democrats to scale our spending to meet our revenue.
Well, how specifically do you plan to do this?
I mean just give us an example of something you...
Ill give you an example.
Right now the budget is presented by the governor in January.
It's supposedly balanced.
It then falls apart in a few months.
The staff works on it.
A few legislative committees pour over the numbers.
In May, they have a few more meetings.
And then they just go on, and it takes forever to get a budget.
It's always unbalanced.
It's always wrong and it's always late.

And what I'm proposing is this December, if I'm elected, to meet with all 120 legislators to engage them in the process, dismiss their assistants while we really grapple with it, get each of the legislators to own the solution and the problem and yes, work with their staff, but also learn it for themselves with me as governor and we'll work it through.
We'll keep the public informed.
We'll bring in the lobbyists.
We'll bring in the corporate shapers of Republican policy, the union leaders that the Democrats so often listen to.

We'll get the dynamics of power in California focused on this challenge that will not be solved by blaming but by a collective decision to roll up our sleeves and do it in a transparent inclusionary way.
That has never been done in the history of this state and that's what I'm proposing to do to get over this logjam.
You were just 36 when you first became governor in the mid-70s.
If you win this time, you'll be 72.
What mistakes did you make the first time around that you learned from that will sort of guide your thinking about how to run California a second time?
Well, first, I made a mistake in running for president in 1980.
That's something that I've long reflected on.
Number two, I didnt realize when I was younger how important personalities are of each of the legislators.
Lyndon Johnson got things done because he knew people.
He knew their psychology; he listened.
And as governor this time, I would work with all the legislators forging the kind of consensus that we need.
And third, I understand that its not just about new ideas.
You have to have a sequential set of steps incrementally making the changes and laying one brick upon another to get the edifice that youre building actually completed.
So would you say back then maybe you were a bit too dismissive, maybe even a little bit arrogant?
Well, no. I wouldnt use those adjectives.
But I would say I was certainly a young man in a hurry.
And now at this stage of my life I'm ready to focus like a laser beam on this budget crisis and engage people from all political backgrounds in the solution.
The first time around you chose to live in a one-bedroom apartment rather than the governor's mansion.

The first time I was a bachelor.

No.

People are just - theyve discounted all, almost all of the nuttiness.
